milestones: Asexual ants discovered
Tobacco attracts predators with chemicals in response to caterpillars, a study finds
2006 Nobel Prize in Medicine awarded to American scientists
Discovery sheds light on flow of water in carbon nanotubes
2006 Nobel Prize in chemistry for insight into cells
RNA journal submits articles to Wikipedia
Indian lunar mission Chandrayaan finds water on moon
Nobel Prize winner Arthur Kornberg dies at age 89
Scientists improve cancer research techniques
Stanford physicists print smallest-ever letters 'SU' at subatomic level of 1.5 nanometres tall
New fossils from 10 million year old ape found in Ethiopia
Premature aging disease reversed in cells
Spain's new cabinet has more women than men
Study suggests 'sleeping sickness' parasite mutated to evade immune system defences
New rodent discovery leads to new mammal family
Delaware scientists create shortest ever metal to metal bond
Cheap, safe drug shows potential to kill cancer cells

duck: Diatomic molecule - Diatomic molecules are molecules composed only of two atoms, of either the same or different chemical elements.
Van der Waals molecule - A van der Waals molecule is a stable cluster consisting of two or more molecules held together by van der Waals forces or by hydrogen bonds.
molecule definition: the smallest particle of a substance that retains all the properties of the substance and is composed of one or more atoms.
A molecule  is an electrically neutral group of two or more atoms held together by covalent chemical bonds.
Molecular geometry - Molecular geometry is the three-dimensional arrangement of the atoms that constitute a molecule.
Small molecule - In the fields of pharmacology and biochemistry, a small molecule is a low molecular weight (quince orchard high school
Chemical polarity - In chemistry, polarity refers to a separation of electric charge leading to a molecule or its chemical groups having an electric dipole or multipole moment.
Atom - The atom is a basic unit of matter that consists of a dense central nucleus surrounded by a cloud of negatively charged electrons.
A molecule  is an electrically neutral group of two or more atoms held together by covalent chemical bonds.

wiki.text:
(left and center) and 2D (right) representations of the terpenoid
 molecule atisane]]

A 'molecule' is an electrically neutral group of two or more atoms held together
by covalent chemical bonds.<ref
name="iupac"></ref><ref></ref><ref></ref><ref></ref><ref></ref><ref></ref>
Molecules are distinguished from ions by their lack of electrical charge.
However, in quantum physics, organic chemistry, and biochemistry, the term
molecule is often used less strictly, also being applied to polyatomic ions.

In the kinetic theory of gases, the term molecule is often used for any gaseous
particle regardless of its composition. According to this definition, noble gas
atoms are considered molecules despite being composed of a single non-bonded
atom.<ref></ref>

A molecule may be homonuclear, that is, it consists of atoms of a single
chemical element, as with oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>); or it may be a chemical
compound composed of more than one element, as with water (H<sub>2</sub>O).
Atoms and complexes connected by non-covalent bonds such as hydrogen bonds or
ionic bonds are generally not considered single
molecules.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/388236/molecule
Molecule], Encyclopaedia Britannica on-line</ref>

Molecules as components of matter are common in organic substances (and
therefore biochemistry). They also make up most of the oceans and atmosphere.
However, the majority of familiar solid substances on Earth, including most of
the minerals that make up the crust, mantle, and core of the Earth, contain many
chemical bonds, but are not made of identifiable molecules. Also, no typical
molecule can be defined for ionic crystals (salts) and covalent crystals
(network solids), although these are often composed of repeating unit cells that
extend either in a plane (such as in graphene) or three-dimensionally (such as
in diamond, quartz, or sodium chloride). The theme of repeated unit-cellular-
structure also holds for most condensed phases with metallic bonding, which
means that solid metals are also not made of molecules. In glasses (solids that
exist in a vitreous disordered state), atoms may also be held together by
chemical bonds without presence of any definable molecule, but also without any
of the regularity of repeating units that characterises crystals.
wiki.title: Molecule
